Google Maps has become an indispensable tool for millions of people worldwide, offering accurate navigation and helping users seamlessly move from one destination to another. But how does Google manage to deliver such precise routes and real-time updates? The answer lies in a sophisticated blend of data collection, artificial intelligence (AI), and real-time analysis. By leveraging a wide array of data sources—ranging from satellite imagery to GPS data from smartphones—Google Maps continuously refines its navigation capabilities to provide users with the most reliable routes and traffic updates.Beyond simple directions, Google Maps integrates features like real-time traffic alerts, weather conditions, and personalized recommendations, making it an all-encompassing navigation tool. With the integration of AI technologies such as Gemini and the continuous evolution of machine learning algorithms, Google Maps is not just helping people find the fastest route but also offering contextual information that enhances the entire travel experience.One of the foundational components of Google Maps is its use of satellite imagery. High-resolution images from satellites provide a bird’s-eye view of the world, allowing Google to map streets, landmarks, natural features, and urban developments accurately. This data is frequently updated to reflect changes such as new roads, construction zones, and infrastructure developments.In addition to satellite images, Google employs aerial photography captured from aircraft to enhance the granularity of the data. This dual approach ensures that both urban and rural areas are mapped with high accuracy. Google Maps relies heavily on GPS data from millions of smartphones worldwide. As users navigate with Google Maps, anonymized location data is transmitted back to Google, allowing the system to analyze traffic flow, vehicle speed, and road conditions in real-time. This crowdsourced data is invaluable in providing up-to-the-minute traffic updates, identifying congested areas, and suggesting alternate routes.In many urban centers, traffic cameras and sensors installed along roads provide real-time visuals and data on traffic conditions. Google integrates this data to offer users accurate traffic reports, including details about accidents, construction work, and road closures.Google’s Local Guides program plays a significant role in refining map accuracy. With over 300 million local guides contributing reviews, photos, and updates, Google Maps can offer detailed insights into businesses, landmarks, and public spaces. Additionally, users can report changes in road layouts, business openings or closings, and temporary obstructions, ensuring that the maps remain up-to-date.Artificial Intelligence has revolutionised how Google Maps processes and delivers data. By using machine learning algorithms, Google can analyze vast amounts of information from multiple sources and provide real-time updates. This AI-driven approach ensures that maps are constantly updated with the latest information, such as newly constructed roads, traffic accidents, and road hazards.In October 2024, Google introduced a transformative feature by integrating its generative AI chatbot, Gemini, into Google Maps. This feature allows users to conduct highly specific searches, such as “dog-friendly sports bars with outdoor seating and TVs”, offering a more personalized navigation experience. Gemini analyzes reviews, photos, and location data to provide tailored recommendations based on users' preferences.Google Maps now includes immersive weather updates along users' routes, enhancing the navigation experience. Users can see real-time weather forecasts, including rainfall, snow conditions, and extreme weather warnings, which help in planning safe and efficient travel. Additionally, users receive alerts about bad road conditions, flood-prone areas, and accident hotspots, ensuring they are well-informed before and during their journey.Google Maps utilises Large Language Models (LLMs) to process information from over 250 million places globally. These models allow the platform to understand user queries more effectively and deliver precise search results. Whether users are searching for nearby restaurants, gas stations, or tourist attractions, the AI models analyze data from various sources to offer relevant suggestions.For example, if a user searches for “best vegan cafes near me”, Google Maps will not only list the nearest options but also provide ratings, reviews, and photos contributed by other users, giving a comprehensive view of each location.Google Maps’ integration with Google Earth offers users a more immersive experience, allowing them to visualize locations in 3D and explore terrain features in detail. This is particularly useful for hikers, urban planners, and real estate professionals who need an in-depth view of specific areas.As AI continues to evolve, Google Maps aims to provide even more personalized navigation experiences. By analyzing user behavior, preferences, and historical data, Google Maps can suggest routes and destinations that align with individual needs. For instance, frequent commuters may receive updates on traffic patterns specific to their daily routes, while travelers might get recommendations for scenic drives or tourist attractions.Future developments will likely include enhanced safety features, such as real-time hazard detection and predictive traffic modeling. These tools can alert users to potential dangers, such as sharp turns, steep inclines, or sudden weather changes, improving overall road safety.Google Maps is also focusing on promoting sustainable transportation. The platform already offers eco-friendly routing options, which suggest routes that minimize fuel consumption and carbon emissions. Future updates may include more robust features to support electric vehicle (EV) users, such as real-time charging station availability and battery optimization routes.
Article Summary: Artificial Intelligence has revolutionised how Google Maps processes and delivers data. By using machine learning algorithms, Google can analyze vast amounts of information from multiple sources and provide real-time updates. This AI-driven approach ensures that maps are constantly updated with the latest information, such as newly constructed roads and road hazards.

Article Title: Elon Musk and DOGE sued; the complaint says: DOGE obtaining OPM records violated ...
Article Text:
File picture (AP Photo/Alex Brandon, File)

What the lawsuit says



Over 100 current and former federal employees have filed a lawsuit against Elon Musk and the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), accusing them of improperly accessing sensitive personnel records without the necessary approval or security clearance. The lawsuit, which was filed on Tuesday in the Southern District of New York, was initiated by the Electronic Frontier Foundation and other privacy organizations, representing 103 workers and various government employee unions.The plaintiffs are seeking to have the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the government’s primary human resources agency, revoke access to DOGE and its affiliates.According to the lawsuit, the OPM granted DOGE and its agents "administrative" access to its systems, despite the agents—many of whom are under 25 and were recently employed by Musk's private companies—failing to undergo the standard national security background checks.The legal complaint names Musk, DOGE, the OPM, and OPM Director Charles Ezell as defendants. The plaintiffs argue that DOGE's access to OPM records constitutes a violation of the Privacy Act, which prohibits unauthorized access to personal information, even between federal agencies.The lawsuit asserts that OPM’s release of personnel data to DOGE was illegal, as DOGE lacked a legitimate reason to access the records, and there are no exceptions under the Privacy Act that would justify their access.Additionally, the lawsuit highlights that many of DOGE’s agents were not government employees at the time they accessed OPM’s networks, including 19-year-old DOGE employee Edward Coristine, who reportedly used the alias “Big Balls” online. Coristine was dismissed from a cybersecurity firm after an internal investigation into data leaks during his tenure.
Article Summary: The lawsuit was initiated by the Electronic Frontier Foundation and other privacy organizations, representing 103 workers and various government employee unions. The plaintiffs are seeking to have the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the government’s primary human resources agency, revoke access to DOGE.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman provided extensive insights into the future of artificial intelligence and its underlying economics in a detailed blog post released on Sunday, February 9. In his post, Altman explained that continuous and predictable gains in AI performance can be achieved by investing "arbitrary amounts of money." He emphasised that the intelligence of an AI model is approximately proportional to the logarithm of the resources—primarily training compute, data, and inference compute—used in its development.Altman also highlighted that user costs for accessing AI systems are expected to fall by a factor of 10 every 12 months, noting a dramatic drop in token costs from GPT-4 in early 2023 to GPT-4o in mid-2024. These observations were shared on the eve of the two-day Paris AI Action Summit, which began on February 10, where Altman is scheduled to speak on the sidelines.In his blog post, Altman noted that continuous improvements in AI performance are closely linked to the amount of resources dedicated to training and running AI models. He stated, “The intelligence of an AI model roughly equals the log of the resources used to train and run it.” This relationship implies that as long as significant investments continue in training compute, data acquisition, and inference compute, AI systems will see predictable and steady performance gains. Altman expressed confidence that there is no imminent reason for these investments to plateau, suggesting that the pace of improvement will continue as long as funding is available.Altman also addressed the economic aspect of AI usage for end users. He believes that the cost to access AI systems at a given performance level will decrease by 10 times every 12 months. This trend is evidenced by the substantial reduction in the cost per token—from the early deployment of GPT-4 in 2023 to the rollout of GPT-4o in mid-2024, where prices dropped by approximately 150 times. Such reductions are expected to spur broader adoption of AI systems, making advanced AI capabilities more accessible across various industries and applications.The blog post comes in the wake of competitive pressures in the AI industry, notably following the emergence of DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup. DeepSeek claims to have developed a cutting-edge AI model at a fraction of the cost incurred by its U.S. rivals. This development has not only rattled global markets but also sent shock waves across the tech industry, highlighting the intense competition in AI innovation and cost-efficiency.In addition to its operational strategies, OpenAI is reportedly in discussions to raise up to $40 billion in a new funding round. Meanwhile, significant corporate investments have been pledged by companies such as Microsoft, Nvidia, Arm, Oracle, and Softbank. Collectively, these partners have committed approximately $500 billion over the next four years to develop AI infrastructure in the United States, including data centers, energy plants, and power lines. This massive influx of capital underscores the industry's confidence in the transformative potential of AI and its long-term economic impact.Addressing the ongoing debate between open-source and closed AI models, Altman acknowledged the need to provide users with greater control over technology. He noted, “Many of us expect to need to give people more control over the technology than we have historically, including open-sourcing more, and accept that there is a balance between safety and individual empowerment that will require trade-offs.” This perspective comes as OpenAI rethinks its open-source strategy in light of the growing popularity of open-source reasoning models like DeepSeek’s R1, which have challenged conventional closed systems.Altman discussed the concept of artificial general intelligence (AGI), describing it as a system capable of solving complex problems across various domains at or above human-level performance. While he believes that AGI-level systems are on the near horizon, some experts contend that such capabilities may still be a decade away. Altman envisions a future where AGI is deployed on a massive scale, with millions of AI agents operating across all fields of knowledge work. He also opined on the potential economic effects, suggesting that while the cost of many goods will eventually fall dramatically due to lower intelligence and energy costs, the price of luxury items and inherently limited resources like land may rise significantly.Altman touched upon the need for early intervention to prevent an imbalance of power between capital and labor as AI systems become more integrated into society. He warned that some decisions and limitations related to AGI safety, which may prove unpopular, could become necessary. Additionally, Altman expressed concerns about the potential use of AI for mass surveillance by authoritarian governments, emphasizing the critical need to ensure that the benefits of AGI are broadly and equitably distributed.In a clarifying footnote, Altman stated that his views on AGI do not affect OpenAI’s long-term relationship with Microsoft. Despite differences in internal definitions—Microsoft reportedly defines AGI as an AI system that generates at least $100 billion in profits—the partnership remains strong. Microsoft has invested over $13 billion in OpenAI over the years, and Altman reiterated, “We fully expect to be partnered with Microsoft for the long term,” underscoring the strategic alliance between the two companies.
Article Summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman explains how AI intelligence scales with resources. Altman predicts AI access costs will drop 10x every year. He also opined on the potential economic effects, suggesting that many goods will eventually fall dramatically due to lower intelligence and energy costs.

Securities & Exchange Board of India ( SEBI ) has seized Rs 53.67 crore from Asmita Patel Global School of Trading Pvt Ltd along with five other entities. Some of the popular courses offered by the self-proclaimed "options queen" and "She Wolf of Stock Market" are "Let's Make India Trade" (LMIT), "Master's in Price Action Trading" (MPAT), and "Options Multiplier" (OM) .Jayesh Thakkar, a SEBI Registered Research Analyst shared a post on X (formerly Twitter) stating “SEBI has seized Rs 53.67 crore that Asmita Patel and five other related entities made illegally. In addition to impounding the Rs 53.67 crore, SEBI has issued a show-cause notice questioning why Rs 104.6 crore, collected as fees for various programs, should not also be seized.SEBI has sent an interim order directing the school, Asmita Jitesh Patel, and Jitesh Jethalal Patel to cease offering unregistered investment advisory and research analyst services. The entities have also been barred from accessing the securities market.The order also uncovered that fees collected from participants were routed through entities such as King Traders (proprietor: Sagar Dhanjibhai), Gemini Enterprise (proprietor: Suresh Parmashivam), and United Enterprises (proprietor: Jigar Rameshbhai Dawada). Recommendations of buy/sell of specific securities were provided and uploaded on telegram channels owned by the Noticee no.1. The acts of the Noticee no.1 makes it evident that it was providing investment advice/ research analyst services to students/investors/participants for a consideration in the pretext of imparting education.”

Reports have surfaced of internal debates at Microsoft regarding the future of the labs. The New York Times reported in January 2024 that Microsoft has held internal debates for years on whether to shutter or relocate its AI labs in China. Among the key concerns is that top researchers could leave the company to join Chinese companies with ties to the CCP, or even that China could hack the company's labs.Microsoft has dismissed claims of plans to shut down its labs, even though it previously encouraged some China-based employees to explore relocation to other countries. Meanwhile, lawmakers have cautioned Microsoft about its close collaboration with China on AI development. Notably, there is no evidence suggesting any misconduct by DeepSeek employees connected to Microsoft.
Article Summary: Microsoft Research Asia, comprising labs in Beijing and Shanghai, has faced increasing political pressure in Washington, with executives reportedly debating the future of the facilities. Among the DeepSeek employees with Microsoft ties is a researcher who spent six years as a research intern in the lab’s natural language computing group.

Article Title: Google's former CEO Eric Schmidt has a DeepSeek warning for the US
Article Text:
Eric Schmidt on Sam Altman’s approach

Schmidt on AI regulation by Europe

Eric Schmidt , former Google CEO , has cautioned Western nations about the need to invest in open-source artificial intelligence models, warning they risk falling behind China in the global AI race, a report has said.“If we don’t do something about that, China will ultimately become the open-source leader and the rest of the world will become closed-source,” Schmidt told the Financial Times, while pointing out that most leading US LLMs, including Google's Gemini, Anthropic's Claude, and OpenAI's GPT-4, are closed (not freely accessible), with Meta's Llama being a notable exception.He emphasised that neglecting open-source technologies could hinder scientific progress in Western universities, which might struggle to afford expensive closed models.His warning follows the recent launch of DeepSeek's R1, an open AI large language model developed in China with impressive efficiency, surpassing some US competitors like OpenAI.Schmidt also commented on OpenAI CEO Sam Altman ’s comment on being on the “wrong side of history” regarding open-source models, signaling that the company might need to shift away from its reliance on costly closed models.“I think [Altman] was a bit too hasty,” commented Schmidt, arguing that the future of AI leadership will depend on effectively integrating both open- and closed-source models.Notably, US tech giants like Google and Amazon have heavily invested in closed models, betting that this approach will maximise returns on their substantial investments. Notably, Facebook-parent Meta has been the only major tech company that has made its Llama AI models open source.Schmidt made these remarks at the AI Action Summit in Paris, where US Vice President JD Vance criticised EU regulation on AI technology, saying that “excessive regulation of the AI sector could kill a transformative industry.”“Europe’s got to get its act together. The application layer is profoundly powerful, and it will make your Europe more efficient,” Schmidt said.
Article Summary: Eric Schmidt warns Western nations about need to invest in open-source AI. Warns they risk falling behind China in the global AI race. Most leading US LLMs, including Google's Gemini, Anthropic's Claude, and OpenAI's GPT-4, are closed.

Article Title: SEBI launches Mitra to help you track trace and claim inactive Mutual Fund portfolios and more
Article Text: The Securities and Exchange Board of India ( SEBI ) has introduced a new digital platform called Mutual Fund Investment Tracing and Retrieval Assistant ( MITRA ) to assist investors in tracking and reclaiming inactive or unclaimed mutual fund folios. This initiative aims to address the growing concern of investors losing track of their mutual fund investments due to outdated contact information or unawareness of investments made in their name.The MITRA platform, managed by Computer Age Management Services Limited (CAMS) and KFIN Technologies Limited, will provide investors with a searchable database of inactive and unclaimed mutual fund folios. Inactive folios are defined as those with no investor-initiated transactions, financial or non-financial, for a period of ten years, despite having a unit balance.SEBI's circular emphasised that the platform will help investors identify overlooked investments or any investments made by others for which they may be rightful legal claimants. The platform will also encourage investors to complete their Know Your Customer (KYC) process, reducing the number of non-KYC compliant folios and minimising the risk of fraudulent redemptions.The MITRA platform will be available through a link on the websites of MF Central, AMCs, AMFI, the two QRTAs, and SEBI. It is expected to be operational within 15 working days from the issuance of the circular. The platform will also comply with SEBI's guidelines for Business Continuity Plan (BCP) and Disaster Recovery (DR) to ensure its reliability and security.SEBI has directed all stakeholders, including AMCs, RTAs, RIAs, AMFI, and mutual fund distributors, to create awareness about this initiative among investors. The launch of MITRA is part of SEBI's broader strategy to enhance investor protection and ensure the integrity of the mutual fund industry.
Article Summary: The Securities and Exchange Board of India ( SEBI ) has introduced a new digital platform called Mutual Fund Investment Tracing and Retrieval Assistant ( MITRA) This initiative aims to assist investors in tracking and reclaiming inactive or unclaimed mutual fund folios.

Article Title: Hacker claims access to 20 million-plus ChatGPT access codes: What ChatGPT users should do right away
Article Text:
How this alleged data breach can affect users



What ChatGPT users should do

This raises concerns about the security of OpenAI user accounts.In the statement, (translated from Russian by Malwarebytes), the hacker said: ““When I realized that OpenAI might have to verify accounts in bulk, I understood that my password wouldn’t stay hidden. I have more than 20 million access codes to OpenAI accounts. If you want, you can contact me—this is a treasure.”According to a report by Malwarebytes, such a large number of credentials may not have been harvested solely through phishing attacks on users. However, If the hacker's claim is accurate, Emirking may have discovered a way to compromise the auth0.openai.com subdomain, either by exploiting a vulnerability or by obtaining administrator credentials. However, OpenAI has to yet to officially address the hacker’s claims.Stolen OpenAI credentials could potentially allow cyber criminals to access sensitive user information, leading to targeted phishing campaigns and financial fraud. Additionally, the credentials could be used to exploit the OpenAI API , forcing victims to pay for unauthorized usage of premium features. However, some users on the dark web forum where the credentials were shared have claimed that they do not provide access to ChatGPT conversation history.Users are advised to change their passwords, enable multi-factor authentication and monitor their accounts for any suspicious activity. It is also important to be vigilant against phishing attempts that may leverage stolen information.BreachForums, the dark web platform where the credentials were reportedly offered, is currently offline, preventing immediate verification of the claims. However, users can also utilise online tools like Malwarebyte’s Digital Footprint scan to check for exposed personal data.

Article Title: Infosys layoffs: Company cites this clause in trainees contract; says all freshers get …
Article Text:
Poll Are IT Layoff Clauses a Trap for Freshers? No, It’s Standard Practice Yes, They Create Uncertainty

Infosy has terminated approximately 400 trainees at its Mysore campus after they failed to clear mandatory internal assessments, leaving many stranded and emotional as they were asked to immediately vacate the premises.The mass termination, which took place on February 7, affected trainees who had waited two and a half years to join the company after receiving their offer letters in 2022, MoneyControl reported."This is cruelty, it is a big company, trainees fear speaking the truth," a terminated trainee told MoneyControl on condition of anonymity.The company defended its actions in a statement to PTI, saying, "All freshers get three attempts to clear the assessment, failing which they will not be able to continue with the organisation.” This is also mentioned in their contract, and the process has been in existence for over two decades, says the company.The terminations were carried out systematically, with groups of 50 trainees called in with their laptops starting at 9:30 AM. Security personnel and bouncers were present during the proceedings, sources revealed.One particularly emotional scene unfolded when a female trainee from Madhya Pradesh pleaded with officials, "Please let me stay the night. I will leave tomorrow. Where will I go right now?" However, company officials reportedly responded, "We don't know. You are no longer part of the company. Vacate the premises by 6 pm."The situation may worsen as another 450 trainees from the October 21 batch are scheduled for their third assessment attempt on February 14, sources told MoneyControl.Critics point to drastic changes in the evaluation system. The passing criteria has been raised from 50% to 65%, while the training syllabus has been expanded significantly. The current system requires approximately 200 hours of study, with trainees expected to put in an additional eight hours of self-study daily."This blatant corporate exploitation cannot be allowed to continue, and we urge the government to take swift action to uphold the rights and dignity of Indian IT workers," said Harpreet Singh Saluja of NITES in a statement.

Article Title: Facebook employees used Torrent to download 81.7TB of data to train its LLaMA: Court papers
Article Text: Meta, Facebook 's parent company, faces a class action lawsuit alleging copyright infringement and unfair competition in training its LLaMA AI model , according to court records revealed by vx-underground on X. First reported by Tom's Hardware, vx-underground's post on Twitter claims how court documents from February 5th, 2024, in Kadrey v. Meta show Meta (formerly Facebook) illegally Torrented 81.7TB of data from "shadow libraries" such as Anna's Archive, Z-Library, and LibGen to train Meta artificial intelligence.The lawsuit claims that internal communications show Meta researchers expressing concerns about using pirated material as early as October 2022, with one senior AI researcher stating, “I don’t think we should use pirated material. I really need to draw a line here.” Another AI researcher says, "using pirated material should be beyond our ethical threshold" ... "SciHub, ResearchGate, LibGen are basically like PirateBay or something like that, they are distributing content that is protectec by copyright and they're infringing it".Despite these concerns, documents show Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg saying in January 2023, “We need to move this stuff forward... we need to find a way to unblock all this.” Three months later, an employee expressed concern about Meta IP addresses being used for downloading pirated content, adding, “torrenting from a corporate laptop doesn’t feel right.” The documents also suggest Meta took steps to conceal its downloading activity.This isn't the first such lawsuit. Other AI companies like OpenAI and Nvidia have faced similar accusations regarding data used for training their models. OpenAI was sued by novelists in June 2023, with The New York Times following suit in December. Nvidia also faced a lawsuit for using copyrighted books, and a former employee revealed extensive video scraping for AI training . OpenAI is now investigating whether DeepSeek illegally obtained data from ChatGPT.The case against Meta is ongoing, and a court decision on direct infringement is pending. Regardless of the initial outcome, appeals are likely, potentially delaying a final judgment for months or years.
Article Summary: Meta, Facebook's parent company, faces a class action lawsuit alleging copyright infringement and unfair competition in training its LLaMA AI model. Article Title: Apple Maps follows Donald Trump's order, renames 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America'
Article Text:
Reason behind renaming of 'Gulf of Mexico' to 'Gulf of America'



Donald Trump's order officially renames Gulf of Mexico via GNIS update



Apple’s implementation of the name change of ‘Gulf of Mexico’ to the ‘Gulf of America’



Google’s regional approach to mapping updates



Microsoft’s update on Bing Maps

In a move that has drawn widespread attention from both the public and the tech community, Apple has updated its digital maps by renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America . According to reports, this change was implemented on Tuesday after an official order by President Donald Trump was confirmed by the U.S. Geographic Names Information System (GNIS). The renaming reflects an ongoing effort to align digital mapping data with government directives, following a similar announcement by other major tech companies. With Apple making the update promptly, users around the world will now see the revised name on their devices. This article provides an in-depth analysis of the background, implementation, and implications of the change across various digital platforms.The renaming of the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America originates from a directive issued by President Donald Trump shortly after taking office. The order targeted the body of water bordered by the Southern United States, Mexico, and Cuba. The U.S. Geographic Names Information System later formalized the change, updating the official records late on Sunday. This directive has since prompted major digital map providers to adjust their geographic data in accordance with the updated government listing. The process underscores the significant influence that official government orders can have on digital infrastructure and mapping services used by millions of people daily.After assuming office, President Trump ordered that the water body traditionally known as the Gulf of Mexico be renamed to better reflect geopolitical perspectives. This order was subsequently made official when the U.S. Geographic Names Information System updated its records late Sunday. The GNIS update served as the formal basis for digital map providers to implement the new nomenclature across their platforms. By adhering to the GNIS update, companies ensure that their mapping data remains accurate and consistent with official U.S. government standards.Apple acted swiftly on the official update by renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America on its mapping service. As of Tuesday, users accessing Apple Maps can see the updated nomenclature. This change demonstrates Apple’s commitment to maintaining current and government-compliant geographic information in its products. By updating its maps in response to the GNIS directive, Apple aligns its digital services with official records, ensuring that users receive accurate and up-to-date geographic information.Google announced last month that it would implement the renaming once the official GNIS listing was updated. In a blog post released on Sunday, Google explained its approach to the change: users in the United States will see the name Gulf of America, whereas users in Mexico will continue to see the name Gulf of Mexico. For users in other parts of the world, both names will be displayed. This regional differentiation ensures that the mapping service respects local naming conventions while remaining consistent with the updated official data. Google’s method highlights the complexities involved in implementing geographic changes across a diverse, global user base.In addition to Apple and Google, Microsoft has also updated its Bing maps to reflect the new nomenclature. Following the official GNIS update, Microsoft modified its mapping data so that users accessing Bing maps now see the renamed Gulf of America. This coordinated response among major tech companies illustrates how quickly digital mapping platforms can adapt to official government orders and maintain consistency across their services.
Article Summary: Apple has updated its digital maps by renaming Gulf of Mexico to Gulf of America. The change was implemented on Tuesday after an official order by President Donald Trump was confirmed by the U.S. Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) Google announced last month that it would implement the renaming once the official GNIS listing was updated.
